The theory of rates of interest and discount; annuities and sinking funds with practical applications to mortgage and bond questions.
This course provides foundational tools for understanding key financial concepts, such as interest rates, annuities, loans, and bonds.

The principles introduced are essential for performing calculations related to everyday financial matters, like determining mortgage payments or valuing investments, and they play a key role in sectors like banking, insurance, and real estate.

By the end of the course, you will have a strong grasp of the mathematical techniques used to approach real-world financial problems, laying a foundation for further study and practical applications in finance and actuarial science.
You can find the Actuarial Science program and plan requirements in the Undergraduate Academic Calendar.

Multiple state models: applications in life contingencies; assumptions; Kolmogorov equations; premiums, policy values, multiple decrement models.
The objective of this course is to build upon the concepts introduced in ACTSC 232 to analyze more complex life insurance problems.
Explain and calculate expense reserves and modified premium policy values.
Use multiple state models (identifying the Kolmogorov Forward Equations, calculating probabilities, and calculating premiums and policy values) in applications in life and health insurances.
Construct and use multiple decrement models.
Use models for the valuation of insurance benefits on multiple lives in both dependent and independent cases.
You should attempt the questions before reviewing solutions to solidify your understanding of the concepts in lecture.

course_name: ACTSC363 - Casualty and Health Insurance Mathematics 1 (0.50)
topics: Casualty and Health Insurance Mathematics 1 Winter 2025
1:00-2:00pm M3 2101 https://uwaterloo.zoom.us/j/93537460710?pwd=JSSR2TDeSlcgBaTFmtarRzNk2Zcq47.1

Introduction to the collective risk model; models for loss frequency: (a, b, 0) and (a, b, 1) classes of distributions, compound distributions and mixtures; models for loss severity: exponential, gamma, lognormal, Pareto, Weibull, and mixtures; measures of distribution tails; impact of policy adjustments on loss frequency and severity; estimation of frequency and severity models.
identify classes of severity and frequency distributions for modelling loss outcomes and construct new families of distributions;
calculate various measures of tail weight and interpret the results to compare the tail weights;
evaluate the impacts of coverage modifications like deductibles, coinsurance, and policy limits on severity and frequency distributions;
estimate loss and payment distributions using frequency and severity data.
Week Date Chapters Topics
Ch 4: Frequency models Common frequency distributions
8 Week of Mar 3 Mixed-frequency distributions, compound frequency distributions
Bornhuetter-Ferguson method

course_name: ACTSC372 - Investment Science and Corporate Finance (0.50)
topics: Monitor discussions & respond to questions on Piazza.
Introduction to financial markets.
Rigorous derivations of Markowitz portfolio optimization and its application in investment decisions.
Introduction to options, forwards, and swaps.
This course provides a comprehensive introduction to capital markets, investment principles, and financial decision-making.
The course also examines behavioral finance and the limitations of financial models, offering a balanced perspective on modern finance.
Understand the structure and functioning of capital markets and evaluate risk-return trade-offs in investment decisions.
Apply mean-variance optimization to construct efficient portfolios and analyze risk-return trade-offs.
Utilize Arbitrage Pricing Theory (APT) to identify and assess multiple risk factors influencing asset returns.
Understand and apply the Modigliani-Miller (MM) propositions to assess capital structure decisions in perfect markets.
Explain put-call parity and its role in pricing options and identifying arbitrage opportunities.
Analyze the impact of behavioral biases on investor decision-making and market outcomes.
Evaluate the limitations of financial models and theories in real-world applications.
Course Intro & Overview of Financial Markets
Investment Rules & Capital Budgeting
Mean-variance optimization
CAPM & Arbitrage pricing theory (APT)
Dividend policy & Introduction to options
Option Pricing & Expected utility theory
Behavioral finance & course review.
Midterm locations are MC 1085 & EIT 1015.

Aggregate loss and payment models: properties, analytic results, convolution-type methods, recursive methods, inversion-type methods, and simulation; advanced aggregate claims models; reinsurance; applications to insurance pricing; insurance pricing using generalized linear models.
View requirements for ACTSC 431
This course is a continuation of the loss modelling topics covered in ACTSC 363.
Aggregate loss and aggregate payment models will be considered  for applications in insurance contexts.
Chapter 1: Individual risk model
Chapter 2: Collective risk model
Chapter 3: Simulations in loss modelling applications
calculate distributional quantities of interest (mean, variance, VaR, ....) for these aggregate claim models
apply simulation methods in actuarial loss modelling
understand the basic principles of reinsurance to help insurers mitigate the risks of a portfolio of insurance
apply generalized linear models to complete a tariff analysis for a portfolio of non-life insurance policies
In the event you miss a test and your instructor accepts to provide accommodation for the missed test, its test weight will be transferred to the final exam.
Mathematics of Financial Markets Fall 2023
This course covers mathematical techniques for no-arbitrage pricing and hedging financial derivatives.

Topics to be covered can be classified into three broad areas: derivatives markets (options; forwards and futures; other derivatives; put-call parity), discrete-time financial models (binomial models; general multi-period models; Fundamental Theorems of Asset Pricing; risk-neutral probability), and continuous-time financial models (basic stochastic calculus and Itô's lemma; Black-Scholes model; interest rate models and bond pricing).
Introduction to Financial Accounting Winter 2025

AFM 101:
This course is an introduction to financial accounting.
View requirements for AFM 101
Define and use financial accounting terminology.
Identify and correct basic accounting errors in financial statement accounts.
Draw conclusions and make recommendations based on financial information.
Identify and apply the principles of financial reporting.
Apply basic financial accounting principles in an industry.

Mathematical Statistics Winter 2025
This course provides a mathematically rigorous treatment for topics covered in STAT230 and 231, and to make essential extensions to the multivariate case.

Topics covered include independence of random variables, conditional expectation and the determination of the distribution of functions of random variables using the cumulative distribution method, change of variable and moment generating functions.
Asymptotic properties of the maximum likelihood estimator are examined and used to construct confidence intervals or regions.

Topics cover generating functions, conditional probability distributions and conditional expectation, discrete-time Markov chains with a countable state space, limit distributions for ergodic and absorbing chains, applications including the random walk, the gambler's ruin problem, and the Galton-Watson branching process, an introduction to counting processes, connections between the exponential distribution and Poisson process, and non-homogeneous and compound Poisson processes.
use moment generating functions as a tool to determine expected values and identify probability distributions of random variables;
use the law of total expectation to calculate expected values and probabilities through the principle of conditioning;
specify a discrete-time Markov chain (DTMC), in terms of its transition probability matrix and initial conditions, and calculate various transition probabilities;
classify the states of a DTMC;
define fundamental DTMC concepts including irreducibility, periodicity, and recurrence/transience;
find limiting/stationary probability distributions for certain DTMCs through the use of the Basic Limit Theorem;
calculate absorption probabilities and expected absorption times for DTMCs using the principle of conditioning with respect to the first transition;
Week 11 March 24 - March 28 Chap 4: Exponential Distribution & Poisson Processes Tutorial Assignment 2
Week 12 March 31 - April 4 Chap 4: Exponential Distribution & Poisson Processes Tutorial Test 3

Choose appropriate techniques from differential multivariable calculus to solve optimization problems both with and without constraints.
Choose appropriate coordinate systems, build linear mappings, and apply the Change of Variable Theorem to evaluate double and triple integrals.

Topology on RN: completeness, closed and open sets, connectivity, compact sets, continuity, uniform continuity. (~3 weeks)
Differentiation: partial differentiability, differentiability, chain rule, [midterm likely here], Taylor polynomials, extreme value problems. (~4 weeks)
Integration: Jordan content, integrability criteria, Fubini's theorem, change of variables. (~3 weeks)

Local properties of continuously differentiable functions: open mapping theorem, inverse function theorem, implicit function theorem.

Topology of real n-dimensional space: completeness, closed and open sets, connectivity, compact sets, continuity, uniform continuity. Local properties of continuously differentiable functions: open mapping theorem, inverse function theorem, implicit function theorem.

An introduction to numerical methods for ordinary and partial differential equations.
Ordinary differential equations: multistep and Runge-Kutta methods; stability and convergence; systems and stiffness; boundary value problems.
Partial differential equations: finite difference methods for elliptic, hyperbolic and parabolic equations; stability and convergence.
Analyze and implement numerical methods for ordinary differential equations
Analyze and implement finite difference methods for partial differential equations
Runge-Kutta methods: 3 weeks
Linear multistep method: 3 weeks
Computer Methods for Ordinary Differential Equations and Differential-Algebraic Equations.
Numerical Solution of Partial Differential Equations.
A first course in the numerical analysis of differential equations.
Finite Difference Methods for Ordinary and Partial Differential Equations.
SIAM 2007
You can discuss problems and compare answers with your classmates.
Do NOT email me about taking an extension unless your circumstances require a longer extension.

An introductory course in physics for students intending to concentrate their future studies in the physical sciences, optometry, or mathematics; includes vectors (dot and cross products), particle kinematics and dynamics, forces in nature, work and energy, conservation of energy and linear momentum, rotational kinematics and dynamics, and conservation of angular momentum.
Doing Physics - quantities, dimensions, units
Point Dynamics - force, motion, Newton's laws
Conservation of Energy - work and energy, conservative systems
Conservation of linear Momentum - momentum and systems of particles
Understand the following concepts:
- Linear kinematics: the relationship between distance, velocity and acceleration.
- Linear dynamics: a consequence of forces and momentum, and how they interrelate.
- Kinetic energy, potential energy, work, and their interrelationships.
We will also re-examine these concepts in a rotating coordinate frame using angular kinematic variables along with torque and angular momentum.
6 Module 06:  Kinetic and Potential Energy
7 Module 06:  Kinetic and Potential Energy
8 Module 07:  Linear Momentum

Introduction to Computational Mathematics Winter 2025
A rigorous introduction to the field of computational mathematics.
The focus is on the interplay between continuous models and their solution via discrete processes.
Topics include pitfalls in computation, solution of linear systems, interpolation, discrete Fourier transforms, and numerical integration.
Explain the shortcomings of finite precision arithmetic
Analyze problems in terms of conditioning, and algorithms in terms of stability
Know some common and basic algorithms in computational mathematics, e.g. Numerical solution of linear systems, Numerical Integration, etc.
Apply these algorithms to solve problems from various domains
Errors and Error Propagation(Chapter 1)
Floating point numbers and operations (1.2)
Standard floating point systems (1.2.2)
Condition of a Mathematical Problem (1.3)
Four Algorithms for Root Finding (2.2)
Numerical Linear Algebra(Chapter 3)
Algorithm and computational cost (3.2.3)
Week of February 3(V)
Condition and stability(3.3)
Iterative Methods for solving Ax = b (3.4)
Jacobi and Gauss-Seidel Methods (3.4.1)
Week of February 24(VII)
Piecewise Linear Interpolation (5.2.1)
Week of March 3(VIII)
Integration (chapter 6)
Integration of an Interpolating Polynomial (6.1)
Accuracy, Truncation Error and Degree of Precision
Gaussian Integration (6.3)
Week of March 17(X)

Introduction to Differential Equations Winter 2025
Solving linear differential equations: first- and second-order scalar equations and first-order vector equations.
The main purpose of the course is to explore how first and second order differential equations (DEs) are used to model physical systems and predict their behaviour.
first order linear DE models of compartment problems, atomic decay, and bodies in motion;
first order separable DE models of population growth;
a first order exact DE model of the electric dipole;
second order linear DE models for oscillatory systems such as mass-spring-damper systems and electrical circuits;
second order nonlinear DE models for suspended cables and rocket motion;
linear vector DE models of multiple compartment problems and species interactions.
Both analytical solution techniques and qualitative methods (direction field analysis, dimensional analysis, and phase portraits) will be presented as ways to gain information about system behaviour.
We will investigate conditions for existence, uniqueness, and continuity of solutions of both first and second order initial value problems, and for systems in the plane.
Maple will be used to generate numerical and graphical solutions, to illustrate concepts graphically, and to explore model behaviour.
increase your comprehension of some of the many ways that differential equations can help us understand the real world;
develop your ability to understand a mathematical model for a specific situation;
explore analytical and qualitative solution methods for first and second order differential equations, and the use of Maple; and
Please choose only one of the two options below.

course_name: AMATH251 - Introduction to Differential Equations (Advanced Level) (0.50)
topics: Notice of Recording
Introduction to Differential Equations (Advanced Level)
Email: cbauch@uwaterloo.ca
Email: apunnavajhala@uwaterloo.ca
This course offers a more theoretical treatment of differential equations and solution methods.
In addition, emphasis will be placed on computational analysis of differential equations and on applications in science and engineering.
Newton's enthusiasm was due to his success in using differential equations to give the first mathematical description of planetary orbits.

Can you imagine what his reaction would be to the present widespread use of differential equations, with applications ranging from the space shuttle guidance system to epidemic models and neural networks?
learn how to solve simple differential equations
understand how differential equations can be applied in various fields
We will cover portions of the following chapters from Boyce & DiPrima, in order:
Chapter 1: Introduction to DEs
Chapter 2: First-order differential equations
Chapter 3: Second-order differential equations
Chapter 7: Systems of linear equations
Chapter 8: Numerical methods
Chapter 9: Nonlinear differential equations and stability
Elementary Differential Equations and Boundary Value problems.

Complex Analysis Winter 2025
Complex numbers provide the natural setting in which to study differentiable functions.

Cauchy's theorem plays a central role in this subject, and many important results follow from it: Cauchy's integral formula, the theory of Taylor and Laurent series, Cauchy's residue theorem, the argument principle, the fundamental theorem of algebra, the maximum modulus theorem, Mittag-Lefler expansions, and Weierstrass products.

We’ll start the course with a basic review of complex numbers, and the complex exponential and logarithm, complex analytic functions, and make our way towards Cauchy's theorem and its wonderful consequences.
My lectures will draw on a number of books and sources, but I recommend Knopp's Elements of the Theory of Functions, and his Theory of Functions Parts I and II.
Another reference is Marsden and Hoffman's Basic Complex Analysis.
3) analytic functions, Cauchy Riemann equations
6) complex integration
8) Cauchy's Integral Formulas
The gradient vector and the directional derivative.
Multiple integrals in various co-ordinate systems.
Choose appropriate techniques from differential multivariable calculus to solve optimization problems both with and without constraints.
Choose appropriate coordinate systems, build linear mappings, and apply the Change of Variable Theorem to evaluate double and triple integrals.

Unit 3: Continuous Functions

This course includes the independent development and practice of specific skills, such as: analyze functions of two or more variables with respect to limits, continuity, differentiability, and linear approximation; choose appropriate techniques from differential multivariable calculus to solve optimization problems; choose appropriate coordinate systems, build linear mappings, and apply the Change of Variable Theorem to evaluate double and triple integrals.

Topology on RN: completeness, closed and open sets, connectivity, compact sets, continuity, uniform continuity. (~3 weeks)
Differentiation: partial differentiability, differentiability, chain rule, [midterm likely here], Taylor polynomials, extreme value problems. (~4 weeks)
Integration: Jordan content, integrability criteria, Fubini's theorem, change of variables. (~3 weeks)
Local properties of continuously differentiable functions:  open mapping theorem, inverse function theorem, implicit function theorem. (~2 weeks)
Local properties of continuously differentiable functions: open mapping theorem, inverse function theorem, implicit function theorem.

Topology of real n-dimensional space: completeness, closed and open sets, connectivity, compact sets, continuity, uniform continuity. Differential calculus on multivariable functions: partial differentiability, differentiability, chain rule, Taylor polynomials, extreme value problems. Riemann integration: Jordan content, integrability criteria, Fubini's theorem, change of variables. Local properties of continuously differentiable functions: open mapping theorem, inverse function theorem, implicit function theorem.
Notice of Recording
Vector integral calculus-line integrals, surface integrals and vector fields, Green's theorem, the Divergence theorem, and Stokes' theorem.
Applications include conservation laws, fluid flow and electromagnetic fields.
An introduction to Fourier analysis.
Frequency analysis of signals.

course_name: MATH103 - Introductory Algebra for Arts and Social Science (0.50)
topics: Notice of Recording
Introductory Algebra for Arts and Social Science Winter 2025
Email: jen.nelson@uwaterloo.ca
Topics will be chosen from linear equations, systems of linear equations, linear inequalities, functions, set theory, permutations and combinations, binomial theorem, probability theory.
The course begins with a review of operations with real numbers and fundamental algebra skills.
The solutions of polynomial equations, both linear and quadratic, in one and two variables and their graphical representation are studied.
An extension is made to linear systems with their solutions being expressed both algebraically and graphically.
To solve linear systems, matrices and the associated row reduction strategies are used.
The relationship between exponential functions and logarithmic functions is examined.
The basic properties of logarithms are introduced and used to solve logarithmic and exponential equations.
Various applications involving exponential growth and decay and logarithmic scales are presented.
Concepts in set theory and counting theory support the study of probability theory.
Perform operations with real numbers and algebraic expressions.
Solve linear equations and inequalities in one variable, including those involving absolute value, and represent the solutions algebraically and graphically.
Solve a system of linear equations using matrix operations, introducing a free variable, or parameter as appropriate.
Solve quadratic equations in one variable.
Recognize that the solutions to a quadratic equation in two variables lie on a curve known as a parabola and analyze the properties of a parabola.
Describe the relationship between an exponential function and a logarithmic function.
Use the properties of logarithms to solve logarithmic and exponential equations, and to solve problems involving exponential growth and decay, and logarithmic scales.
Use the appropriate symbols and language in set theory to perform set operations, represent sets and subsets using Venn diagrams, and apply the counting principles for sets in real-life situations.

Applied Linear Algebra 1 Winter 2025
Systems of linear equations.
Introduction to vector spaces.
We will see how to solve systems of linear equations using matrix methods before studying matrices as algebraic objects in their own right.
Next, we will learn about the fundamental concepts of span, linear independence, and basis and learn how to determine whether a set is a subspace of Rn.
After studying subspaces, we will study linear mappings, which map subspaces to subspaces.
We will discuss the geometric interpretation of these mappings and study their fundamental subspaces.
Finally, we will learn how to calculate the determinant of a matrix and use this knowledge to diagonalize square matrices.

Linear Algebra 1 (Advanced Level)
Email: karigiannis@uwaterloo.ca
This course is a rigorous treatment of the theory of finite dimensional vector spaces over an arbitrary field.
We also cover the theory of determinants over an arbitrary commutative ring with identity, and some aspects of the theory of polynomials in one variable over a field.

The ultimate goal is the Primary Decomposition Theorem, which characterizes a linear operator on a finite dimensional vector space in terms of invariant subspaces annihilated by the primary factors of its minimal polynomial.
We will cover a large amount of difficult material at a fast pace.
Understand and apply the concepts of the theory of abstract vector spaces and linear operators on finite-dimensional vector spaces.
fields; systems of linear equations; matrices; row-reduced echelon form; matrix algebra; invertible matrices
vector spaces; subspaces; bases and dimension; coordinates; row equivalence
algebra of linear maps; isomorphism; representations by matrices; dual space; transpose of a linear map
commutative rings; existence and uniqueness of determinants; multilinear maps; the exterior algebra
eigenvalues; annihilating polynomials; invariant subspaces; simultaneous triangulation and diagonalization
Much (but not all) of my lectures will closely follow the first six chapters of this book:
“Linear Algebra: Second Edition” by Kenneth Hoffman and Ray Kunze; Prentice Hall, 1971.
“Linear Algebra: Fourth Edition” by Friedberg, Insel, and Spence; Prentice-Hall, 2003.

course_name: MATH104 - Introductory Calculus for Arts and Social Science (0.50)
topics: Introductory Calculus for Arts and Social Science Winter 2025
The major concepts introduced to solve problems are rate of change, optimization, growth and decay, and integration.
This course provides an introduction to the applications of differential and integral calculus in business, the behavioural sciences, and the social sciences.
A special type of limit will give rise to the derivative, the central idea in differential calculus.

The interpretation of the derivative in applications such as rates of change and optimization, where the situations can be modelled by algebraic, exponential, or logarithmic functions, will be examined.
The concepts of the antiderivative and the indefinite integral will be studied.
The Fundamental Theorem of Calculus will relate the integral to the derivative.
The problem of calculating the area under a curve will lead to the definite integral, a basic concept of integral calculus.
The interpretation of the integral in various applications will be studied.
be able to interpret a limit, given the graph of a function;
evaluate the limit of a function using appropriate techniques;
determine the derivative of polynomial functions using the definition of a derivative;
determine the derivative of algebraic, exponential, and logarithmic functions using the techniques of differentiation;
apply the derivative to determining equations of tangents, graphing functions, solving rate problems, and solving optimization problems;
determine general and unique antiderivatives;
determine the indefinite integral of a function using the techniques of integration;
determine definite integrals; and

Introduction to Differential Equations Winter 2025
Solving linear differential equations: first- and second-order scalar equations and first-order vector equations.
The main purpose of the course is to explore how first and second order differential equations (DEs) are used to model physical systems and predict their behaviour.
first order linear DE models of compartment problems, atomic decay, and bodies in motion;
first order separable DE models of population growth;
a first order exact DE model of the electric dipole;
second order linear DE models for oscillatory systems such as mass-spring-damper systems and electrical circuits;
second order nonlinear DE models for suspended cables and rocket motion;
linear vector DE models of multiple compartment problems and species interactions.
Both analytical solution techniques and qualitative methods (direction field analysis, dimensional analysis, and phase portraits) will be presented as ways to gain information about system behaviour.
We will investigate conditions for existence, uniqueness, and continuity of solutions of both first and second order initial value problems, and for systems in the plane.
Maple will be used to generate numerical and graphical solutions, to illustrate concepts graphically, and to explore model behaviour.

course_name: MATH228 - Differential Equations for Physics and Chemistry (0.50)
topics: Differential Equations for Physics and Chemistry Winter 2025
First-order equations, second-order linear equations with constant coefficients, series solutions and special functions, the Laplace transform method.
Applications in physics and chemistry are emphasized.
Differential equations capture how some variable of interest, such as the position of a planet, changes as a function of some independent variable, such as time.
Differential equations are very widely used in the sciences because of the broad range of real-world phenomena they can describe in a mathematical framework.

In this course, students will be introduced to the universe of differential equations, including first-order equations, second-order linear equations, series solutions, the Laplace transform method, and both exact and numerical methods for solving differential equations.
Applications in physics and chemistry will be emphasized.

topics: Introduction to Optimization Winter 2025
walaa.moursi@uwaterloo.ca
Instructor: Walaa Moursi walaa.moursi@uwaterloo.ca
A broad introduction to the field of optimization, discussing applications, and solution techniques.
Mathematical models for real life applications; algorithms; aspects of computational complexity; geometry; linear programming duality, focusing on the development of algorithms.
Carry out the computations by hand for simple instances of various algorithms such as the Simplex.
Formulate the dual of various linear programs.
Reproduce the main proofs in the course and prove simple related concepts independently.
The simplest models are linear programs where both the constraints and the objective functions are linear.
Even though this may appear at a first glance to be overly restrictive, linear programming algorithms are used widely across most branches of industry.
In these cases, we would like to add the condition that some variables in our linear program take integer values only.
These models are known as integer programs.

Finally, in certain instances, such as portfolio optimization (in financial mathematics), the natural way of formulating the optimization problem may require the use of non-linear constraints, or a non-linear objective function.
In the first part of this course, we will illustrate these various models with examples that arise from real problems.
The Simplex algorithm to solve linear programs will be discussed in some detail and general-purpose integer programming techniques such as branch-and-bound and cutting planes will also be described.
These algorithms while guaranteed to terminate, may in the worst case (and often do in practice) take a prohibitively long time.
An indispensable tool for the design of such fast algorithms is the theory of duality, which will be a main focus of this course.
We will move towards the conclusion of the course with a review of the various techniques used to solve linear and integer programs and by providing a geometric interpretation of these algorithms.
This discussion will lead us to non-linear convex optimization problems.
Also included in this last part of the material are approximation algorithms.
Shows a linear programming polytope together with a possible path (red) taken by the simplex method to solve the corresponding LP.

System theory in both time and frequency domain, state-space computations, stability, system uncertainty, loopshaping, linear quadratic regulators and estimation.
The aim of this course is to provide a solid understanding of the mathematical foundations of control theory for linear systems.

Topics to be covered include state space and frequency domain representations, controllability and observability, open and closed loop stability, state feedback and stabilization, detectability, observers and linear quadratic regulators.
Both theoretical and practical aspects of the material will be addressed.

Introduction to Signals and Systems: Continuous-time (CT) and discrete-time (DT) signals, properties of signals and systems, system models.
2. Time-Domain Analysis of Continuous-Time Systems: Zero-input response, impulse response, zero-state response, convolution, stability, system behavior.
3. Time-Domain Analysis of Discrete-Time Systems:  System models, zero-input response, impulse response, zero-state response, stability, system behavior.

Frequency-Domain Analysis of Continuous-Time Systems: Laplace transform (LT) and its properties, system response using LT, stability, electrical transformed networks, block diagrams, system realization, application to control systems, frequency response.
Frequency-Domain Analysis of  Discrete-Time Systems:  Z-transform (ZT) and its properties, system response using ZT, stability, system realization, frequency response.

7. Continuous-Time Non-Periodic Signal Analysis – The Fourier Transform: The Fourier transform (FT) and its properties, system response using FT, ideal and practical filters, Parseval’s theorem, application to communication systems.

View requirements for ECE 380
The principles of automatic control are employed throughout many branches of engineering:
in analog electronics, feedback makes amplifier gains less sensitive to variations in transistor parameters, and improves input and output impedances and frequency response;
in chemical and mechanical engineering applications, automatic controllers regulate temperatures, pressures and flow rates against a range of disturbances;
robots robustly perform high-speed, precision manufacturing operations by means of numerous feedback controllers acting in concert to adjust respective joint angles;
automobiles incorporate computer-based ignition, emission control, braking and cruise control systems, and some, of course, are self-driving;
This course is an introduction to these valuable engineering principles.
system stability;
'tracking' of reference inputs, through the manipulation of control inputs;

The mathematical framework is that of linear time-invariant systems -- in both the time and frequency domains; the main system model is the transfer-function representation of single-input, single-output systems.
Within this framework, the course develops the elements of "classical" analysis and design of feedback control systems.
Describe typical architectures of automatic control systems (e.g., open- and closed-loop).
Derive linear models of dynamic systems from the relevant physical laws.
Manipulate and analyze block-diagram representations of linear, time-invariant systems.
Analyze the responses of linear, time-invariant systems in both the time and frequency domains.
Analyze the bounded-input, bounded-output stability of feedback systems.
Quantify and analyze the performance of control systems in both the transient and steady-state regimes.
Sketch the root locus, and analyze the effects of varying parameters on the poles or eigenvalues of closed-loop systems.
Design controllers or compensators using the root locus to position closed-loop poles.
Draw Nyquist plots, and use them to determine both absolute and relative stability of feedback systems.
Design controllers or compensators on the basis of open-loop frequency-response data.

Introduction to Optimization Winter 2025
walaa.moursi@uwaterloo.ca
Instructor: Walaa Moursi walaa.moursi@uwaterloo.ca
A broad introduction to the field of optimization, discussing applications, and solution techniques.
Mathematical models for real life applications; algorithms; aspects of computational complexity; geometry; linear programming duality, focusing on the development of algorithms.
Carry out the computations by hand for simple instances of various algorithms such as the Simplex.
Formulate the dual of various linear programs.
Reproduce the main proofs in the course and prove simple related concepts independently.
The simplest models are linear programs where both the constraints and the objective functions are linear.
Even though this may appear at a first glance to be overly restrictive, linear programming algorithms are used widely across most branches of industry.
In these cases, we would like to add the condition that some variables in our linear program take integer values only.
These models are known as integer programs.

Finally, in certain instances, such as portfolio optimization (in financial mathematics), the natural way of formulating the optimization problem may require the use of non-linear constraints, or a non-linear objective function.
In the first part of this course, we will illustrate these various models with examples that arise from real problems.
The Simplex algorithm to solve linear programs will be discussed in some detail and general-purpose integer programming techniques such as branch-and-bound and cutting planes will also be described.
These algorithms while guaranteed to terminate, may in the worst case (and often do in practice) take a prohibitively long time.
An indispensable tool for the design of such fast algorithms is the theory of duality, which will be a main focus of this course.
We will move towards the conclusion of the course with a review of the various techniques used to solve linear and integer programs and by providing a geometric interpretation of these algorithms.
This discussion will lead us to non-linear convex optimization problems.
Also included in this last part of the material are approximation algorithms.
Shows a linear programming polytope together with a possible path (red) taken by the simplex method to solve the corresponding LP.

Graduate Attribute Program Indicators

A knowledge base for engineering: Demonstrated competence in university level mathematics, natural sciences, engineering fundamentals, and specialized engineering knowledge appropriate to the program.
1a Demonstrate understanding of concepts in mathematics.
1b Demonstrate understanding of concepts in natural science.
1c Demonstrate understanding of engineering fundamentals.
1d Demonstrate understanding of specialized engineering knowledge.
2. Problem Analysis: An ability to use appropriate knowledge and skills to identify, formulate, analyze, and solve complex engineering problems in order to reach substantiated conclusions.

3. Investigation: An ability to conduct investigations of complex problems by methods that include appropriate experiments, analysis and interpretation of data, and synthesis of information in order to reach valid conclusions.
3a Create investigative studies of complex engineering problems.
3b Gather information from relevant sources to address complex engineering problems.

4. Design: An ability to design solutions for complex, open-ended engineering problems and to design systems, components or processes that meet specified needs with appropriate attention to health and safety risks, applicable standards, economic, environmental, cultural and societal considerations.
4a Define design requirements and specifications for complex, open-ended engineering problems.
4b Critically evaluate and compare design choices.
7. Communication skills: An ability to communicate complex engineering concepts within the profession and with society at large.
Professionalism: An understanding of the roles and responsibilities of the professional engineer in society, especially the primary role of protection of the public and the public interest.
8a Articulate the roles and responsibilities of the professional engineer in society with reference to the protection of the public and its interest.
Impact of Engineering: An ability to analyze social and environmental aspects of engineering activities.

Such abilities include an understanding of the interactions that engineering has with the economic, social, health, safety, legal, and cultural aspects of society; the uncertainties in the prediction of such interactions; and the concepts of sustainable design and development and environmental stewardship.
Analyze the social, health, safety, and environmental aspects of an engineering project, incorporating sustainability considerations and environmental stewardship in making decisions.
10a Identify ethical and unethical behavior in professional situations.
10b Identify how an engineer is accountable to multiple stakeholders in engineering practice.
Life-long Learning: An ability to identify and to address their own educational needs in a changing world to sufficiently maintain their competence and contribute to the advancement of knowledge.
12a Identify gaps in their knowledge, skills and abilities.

course_name: COMMST191 - Communication in the Engineering Profession (AE, CIVE, ENVE, GEOE) (0.50)
major_name: Architectural Engineering (Bachelor of Applied Science - Honours)
topics: jclausen@uwaterloo.ca (please do not use the D2L email system)
I monitor my email M-F, 9:00 am - 5:00 pm.
I am teaching multiple communication courses, and especially early in the sememster, I cannot always quickly know whch course you are referring to just from your email.
In this course students in Architectural, Civil, Environmental, and Geological Engineering will enhance oral and written communication competencies in contexts relevant to the engineering profession.
In this course, you will work to enhance your written and oral technical communication competencies in contexts relevant to the engineering profession as well as to your future career.

More generally, in this course, you should anticipate learning what professional norms of technical communication and dominant forms of sharing knowledge prevail within and across the fields of engineering.
Yet this course also attempts to impart awareness and appreciation for how these communicative forms are matters of social context and sites of negotiation and contestation.

By extension, this progression also encourages you to find a place and voice in the conversations within your fields of study and to reflect upon the meaning and shape of available forums for technical communication.
I perceive our classroom as a co-constructed space, in which readings and discussions may frequently challenge your attitudes, your unconsciously held beliefs, or your positions on current issues.
To ensure a safe and open space in which all can converse and learn productively, it is vital that we conduct our relationships with respect and an ethic of care.
Describe and apply conventions, genres, norms, and values of communication in an engineering discipline;
Compose persuasive, audience-specific technical arguments;
Analyze and summarice technical content in clear and concise ways;
Deliver effective oral presentations; and
Appraise and reflect on their own compositions, and those of their peers, to strategically revise and edit documents and presentations
Objectives for Students of Communication Studies
You (students) will understand the complexity of communication as a human process of shared meaning-making in the context of power, history, and culture.

You will increase your capacity to recognize and enhance yours and others’ agency – the ability to make a difference in the world for yourself and others – and understand the implications of your communication behaviors for yourself and others.
Recognize diverse linguistic practices and modes of communication as resources for writers and speakers.

You will understand communication as a practice, and improve your critical and creative communication competencies by developing your ability to use writing, speaking, and other media of communication to create effective and engaging artifacts.

Your will reflect on your role in fostering the public good (the multifaceted well-being of individuals and groups), begin to imagine a better future, and make decisions in your communication that can transform the communities to which you belong.

major_name: Architectural Engineering (Bachelor of Applied Science - Honours)
topics: Soil Mechanics and Foundations Spring 2024
An introduction to soil mechanics principles including state of stress, ground water flow, consolidation and shear strength.
An introduction to design of shallow and deep foundations.

The ‘soil mechanics’ part of the course materials includes origin and formation of soil, soil mineralogy and chemical interaction with water, quantitative description and classification of soil, soil compaction, flow of water through soil, stresses in soil, soil compressibility, and soil strength.
The ‘foundations’ part covers the analysis, design, and construction aspects of foundations (particularly shallow foundations), slopes, and retaining structures.
The objectives of AE 353 are to make students aware of the different geotechnical engineering related issues for building design and to impart knowledge of basic geotechnical designs.
Failure to attend a laboratory session and/or submit a laboratory report without a genuine reason may result in a failed course grade.

Shear Strength: Mohr-Coulomb Failure Theory; Triaxial Test, Unconfined Compression Test, Direct Shear Test; Drained Shear Strength and Friction Angles, Undrained Shear Strength; Critical State

An introduction to the behaviour of wood as an engineering material and design of timber structures based on limit states design principles.
Topics include materials behaviour, selection and design of structural timber members and systems, including beams, joists, columns, connections, shearwalls, and diaphragms.
The design of structural members subjected to tension, compression, bending, and combined axial and bending loading according to the Engineering in wood design standard (CSA O86-14) is addressed.

Further topics include: connection design (e.g., nails, bolts, dowels, rivets), lateral design of light-frame wood structures, gravity design of cross-laminated timber (CLT) structures, and fire safety.
The primary objective of this course is to provide students with the fundamental skills in structural engineering wood design.
Be able to identify, analyze and design tension, compression, and bending elements using the appropriate wood product based on their mechanical and physical properties for the intended application;
Be capable of designing and analyzing light-frame structures through proper identification of the primary gravity and lateral load paths.

topics: Organismal and Evolutionary Ecology Fall 2023
Learn Discussion Board
Email and Appointment Requests

Coverage includes hypothesis testing and the nature of scientific inquiry, basic population genetics, physiological ecology, life histories, dispersal, basic population and community ecology, macroevolution, systematics and classification, as well as functional morphology.
The theory of evolution unites the whole of biology and all living organisms into a coherent body of knowledge, allowing comparisons across all forms of life.
Ecology describes how organisms interact with their environment and each other to create interdependent systems from microscopic to global scales.

These disciplines are fundamentally tied together: evolution is the primary mechanism by which species adapt to their environment; ecological interactions and environmental variability drive natural selection.

You will also carry out simulated lab assignments to test the principles of evolution, design ecological experiments to test alternate hypotheses about the conservation of species and manipulate demographic parameters to test their influence on population growth.
Understand the principles of scientific methodology
Define ecological and evolutionary terms, such as the niche, adaptation, and altruism
Illustrate these mechanisms in the context of course examples
Explain how ecological interactions and evolution are interconnected

Introduction to the biology of bacterial and archaeal organisms.
Topics include cell structure and function, methods of cultivation, genetics, phylogeny and taxonomy, and metabolic and genetic diversity.
The course is intended to provide basic knowledge of the world of microorganisms and consideration of how we study the activities of these small inhabitants of the planet.
The knowledge gained in this course will also prepare you to succeed in more advanced courses in microbiology, microbial ecology, and molecular biology.
Explain the impact of microbiology on the evolution of life and on human society.
Describe the diversity of bacteria, archaea, and microbial eukaryotes and differentiate between the three domains of microbial life based on key characteristics.
List nutritional categories of microbial metabolism and identify appropriate methods for cultivating microorganisms from these categories.
Explain how microorganisms regulate gene expression in order to compete for limited energy and nutrients.
List methods and mechanisms for exchange and manipulation of microbial DNA.
Describe how modern molecular methods have impacted microbiology.

This unit serves as an introduction to the study of the function of the five organ systems examined in this course (nervous, muscular, cardiovascular, respiratory, and immune).
Unit 1 will introduce how the organ systems work together to maintain homeostasis within the body.
The organization of the nervous system will be explored in this unit.
The types of cells found in the central and peripheral nervous system serve as a starting point to discuss their function within the nervous system.
Initially gross structure of skeletal muscle including the structure of a muscle fibre and myofibrils will be examined.
An exploration into the muscle contraction mechanism via excitation-contraction coupling will be examined to explain how muscles work.
This unit will start with an introduction into the heart and components of the cardiovascular system, which will be followed by cardiac muscle contraction mechanism.
In this unit we will examine the structure and function of the respiratory system, incorporating gas laws and ventilation.
Pulmonary function through lung compliance and elastance as well as the control of ventilation will be examined.
This unit will start with the general function of immune system and introduction to the types of pathogens that infect the body.
The anatomy of the immune system will be discussed returning to the role of haematopoiesis.

topics: Field Ecology Winter 2025
**We aim to respond to forum posts and necessary emails within general workday hours (8:30 AM – 4:30 PM) and within 24hrs, except over weekends and holidays.

Introduces the main concepts and principles of ecology; the cycling of elements; energetics and structural organization of major ecological systems; population dynamics; impact of natural resource management practices and urban and industrial development on the environment; incorporating environmental quality considerations into development activities.
The lab sessions include field trips to study natural and disturbed ecosystems, urban and applied ecology.
View requirements for ENVS 200

Such knowledge, called ecoliteracy, will provide a critical basis for your engagement in the 21st century, the “century of the environment”—not least because so many of the environmental issues we face derive in part from a limited understanding of how we are embedded within and dependent upon ecological systems.

Field ecology necessarily harbours an ethical component both because of our natural affinity for life (or ‘biophilia’) and because questions of ecological ‘impact’ and 'quality’ are necessarily value-laden.

In summary, this course introduces the main concepts and principles of ecology; the cycling of elements; energetics and structural organization of major ecological systems; population dynamics; impact of natural resource management practices and urban and industrial development on the environment; incorporating environmental quality considerations into development activities.
The lab sessions include field trips to study natural and disturbed ecosystems, urban and applied ecology.
By the end of this course, you should be on a path to life-long learning as an ecologically-literate citizen.
Demonstrate how these principles apply to real-world situations (in context of lab activities, assignments, and labs), including human interactions with the natural world.
Articulate the elements of scientific inquiry as they apply to ecology/

These course learning outcomes will not only prepare you to be an informed citizen and member of the community of life on earth, but also provide the basis for knowledge, humility, and wisdom in your dealings with ecological problems in your daily life and eventual career.

major_name: Architectural Engineering (Bachelor of Applied Science - Honours)
topics: Environmental Geology Winter 2024
Include Earth 221 in the subject line and your full name and student ID# in the text.

An introduction to geological concepts; the influence of geological factors on the natural environment; Earth processes and natural hazards; Earth resources, including water, energy and mineral resources; waste disposal and pollution; global climatic and environmental change.
Environmental Geology refers to how geologic processes interact with and influence human activities and vice versa.
The goal is to introduce you to basic geologic concepts in order to better understand your natural physical surroundings, such as earthquakes, volcanoes, surface water and glacial processes.
You will also learn about resource availability such as groundwater and fossil fuels and how we impact the environment via waste disposal and other forms of pollution.

As the population of the Earth grows, there is increased demand for limited supplies of natural resources, a growing release of pollutants, and increased development in geologically unstable parts of the world.
These issues result in a variety of hazards and potential problems that societies need to understand and deal with in ways that are beneficial for the Earth and local populations.
Explain the geologic/earth science connections to certain environmental issues
Use geologic terminology and concepts when describing environmental issues
Critique the use of scientific information in the public domain (e.g., media) regarding geologically-related environmental issues

topics: Notice of Recording
HVAC Systems, Equipment, and Energy Efficiency Winter 2025
Selected topics in HVAC systems design with focus on energy-efficiency and environmental-sustainability.
Heating and cooling distribution using air-, water-, and refrigerant-based systems.
Constant- and variable-flow systems.
Heat- and energy-recovery systems.
Vapour-compression refrigeration and heat-pump systems (including air- and geothermal-source heat pumps).

Selected topics in HVAC systems design, with focus on energy-efficiency and environmental-sustainability: heating and cooling distribution using air-, water-, and refrigerant-based systems; constant- and variable-flow systems; heat- and energy-recovery systems; vapor-compression heat-pump systems, including air-and geothermal-source heat pumps.
Course Overview: Achieving significant reductions in building energy consumption will be important in efforts to deal with the environmental and socioeconomic impacts of energy use.
The energy used by heating, ventilating, and air-conditioning (HVAC) systems represents a large portion of the energy consumption of most commercial, institutional, and residential buildings.

This course will introduce selected topics in HVAC systems design, with focus on energy-efficiency and environmental-sustainability: heating and cooling distribution using air-, water-, and refrigerant-based systems; constant- and variable-flow systems; heat- and energy-recovery systems; vapor-compression heat-pump systems, including air- and geothermal-source heat pumps.

Recommended Preparation: It is strongly recommended that students have engaged in prior study of introductory concepts in thermodynamics, heat transfer, and fluid mechanics, including analysis of refrigeration cycles and basic psychrometrics.
Students without this background are expected to undertake additional study to acquire sufficient competency in each topic.
Perform simple thermodynamic calculations for selected HVAC components and systems.

3. Assess the potential for selected energy-saving strategies to operate effectively for a variety of operating conditions and applications.

course_name: ARCH570 - Special Topics in Building Technology and Environmental (0.50)
major_name: Architectural Engineering (Bachelor of Applied Science - Honours)
topics: Architectural Steel Design Fall 2024

A range of special topics courses within building technologies, structures, materials and methods and environmental systems including coursework in alternative energy systems, ecological design and design build.

Using an international database of case studies this course examines in detail the architectural design, specification, fabrication and construction process for Architecturally Exposed Structural Steel (AESS).
The work of the term will use current steel based competitions to explore detailed design application of the material.
· prepare a weekly sketch of a steel detail
The overall intention is to provide you with a high level appreciation of steel structural systems and an adeptness for detailing that is appropriate to the specific project and building type.
The course reflects the research of my book on Architecturally Exposed Structural Steel published by Birkhauser in January 2015.
A major graded element this term will be your sketchbook - much like we did in Building Construction in first year.
Late submissions will be given a grade of zero.
Sketches: We will begin the term with a series of weekly sketches of close up connection details that can be based upon photos from the lectures or sourced online.
Understand the workings of the CISC method of specifying AESS - the category and characteristics system.
2. Understand the critical role of detailing as it plays into the design, fabrication and erection of steel.
Understand the role of the architect in the process, particularly in the selection of detail and splice types as they factor into overall buildability and construction safety.

Course Introduction
A detailed look at the roots of the birth of exposed steel in the British High Tech movement.
The development and details of the new system created by CISC to clarify the design, construction and fabrication of AESS systems.
Topics will also address finishes and corrosion protection as these impact the detailing of an exposed structure.
A look at different ways that we create long spans with structural systems.
A look at the application of modern cast steel via several case studies.
Curved structures can be achieved via several means, all related to the scale of the building, budget and technical means available.
An examination of a range of applications of tension systems for building structures, canopies, roofs and pedestrian bridges.
A look at the methodology I created to assist in understanding and designing diagrid structures.
STEEL AND TIMBER:

STEEL AND GLAZING AND LATTICE SYSTEMS:
An examination of some of the newer cable type glazing systems to see how these work with AESS systems.
The tolerances in glazing systems are even tighter than for finely detailed AESS structures, and these systems are often used together.

course_name: ME573 - HVAC Systems, Equipment, and Energy Efficiency (0.50)
major_name: Architectural Engineering (Bachelor of Applied Science - Honours)
topics: Notice of Recording
HVAC Systems, Equipment, and Energy Efficiency Winter 2025
Selected topics in HVAC systems design with focus on energy-efficiency and environmental-sustainability.
Heating and cooling distribution using air-, water-, and refrigerant-based systems.
Constant- and variable-flow systems.
Heat- and energy-recovery systems.
Vapour-compression refrigeration and heat-pump systems (including air- and geothermal-source heat pumps).

Selected topics in HVAC systems design, with focus on energy-efficiency and environmental-sustainability: heating and cooling distribution using air-, water-, and refrigerant-based systems; constant- and variable-flow systems; heat- and energy-recovery systems; vapor-compression heat-pump systems, including air-and geothermal-source heat pumps.
Course Overview: Achieving significant reductions in building energy consumption will be important in efforts to deal with the environmental and socioeconomic impacts of energy use.
The energy used by heating, ventilating, and air-conditioning (HVAC) systems represents a large portion of the energy consumption of most commercial, institutional, and residential buildings.

This course will introduce selected topics in HVAC systems design, with focus on energy-efficiency and environmental-sustainability: heating and cooling distribution using air-, water-, and refrigerant-based systems; constant- and variable-flow systems; heat- and energy-recovery systems; vapor-compression heat-pump systems, including air- and geothermal-source heat pumps.

Recommended Preparation: It is strongly recommended that students have engaged in prior study of introductory concepts in thermodynamics, heat transfer, and fluid mechanics, including analysis of refrigeration cycles and basic psychrometrics.
Students without this background are expected to undertake additional study to acquire sufficient competency in each topic.
Perform simple thermodynamic calculations for selected HVAC components and systems.
2. Explain operational characteristics of selected energy-saving strategies for HVAC systems.
3. Assess the potential for selected energy-saving strategies to operate effectively for a variety of operating conditions and applications.

major_name: Architectural Engineering (Bachelor of Applied Science - Honours)
topics: Notice of Recording
Introduction to Complex Systems Winter 2025
Professor Paul Fieguth pfieguth@uwaterloo.ca Office Hours: Mondays 4-5pm in E7-6338

The overwhelming majority of societal, ecological and climate issues of pressing importance are complex systems; nonlinear dynamic interacting systems poorly characterized by linear analyses and Gaussian statistics.
This course introduces the mathematics needed to understand such interactions, including nonlinear dynamics, critical and bifurcation behaviours, large-scale systems and power-law distributions.

The mathematical methods will be motivated by extensive examples and case studies such as global warming, energy shortages, desertification, overpopulation, poverty, and economic instability, to be investigated from a systems engineering perspective that will connect mathematical concepts to real-world examples.
Understand the assumptions and limitations behind linear dynamic / Gaussian systems
Understand the mathematical properties of nonlinear dynamic / power-law systems
Be able to abstract / generalize the impacts and implications of nonlinear systems
Be able to draw connections between macroscopic socio-environmental systems

The Science of the Physical World

What does it mean to be a cell biologist?
One group of scientists might explore growing tissues in a laboratory to one day produce artificial skin or organs.

No matter what their question, cell biologists use a similar set of laboratory skills that allow them to peek inside the tiniest of biological units that make up the diversity of organisms we see around us.

Although fundamental techniques like microscopy have hugely advanced since the invention of the light microscope, every cell biologist needs to learn how to properly use a microscope to see cells reliably.
These can be very tricky to use properly but doing so could be the difference between a world-changing discovery and an experiment that no one can replicate.
These and other methods that are integral to working in the cell biology field will be introduced in this laboratory and it is my hope that you will leave confident in these fundamental techniques.
Maintain a well-organized and comprehensive lab book.
Identify elements of a well-structured laboratory report and write some elements of a lab report.

Introduction to the biology of bacterial and archaeal organisms.
Topics include cell structure and function, methods of cultivation, genetics, phylogeny and taxonomy, and metabolic and genetic diversity.
The course is intended to provide basic knowledge of the world of microorganisms and consideration of how we study the activities of these small inhabitants of the planet.
The knowledge gained in this course will also prepare you to succeed in more advanced courses in microbiology, microbial ecology, and molecular biology.
Explain the impact of microbiology on the evolution of life and on human society.
Describe the diversity of bacteria, archaea, and microbial eukaryotes and differentiate between the three domains of microbial life based on key characteristics.
List nutritional categories of microbial metabolism and identify appropriate methods for cultivating microorganisms from these categories.
Explain how microorganisms regulate gene expression in order to compete for limited energy and nutrients.
List methods and mechanisms for exchange and manipulation of microbial DNA.
Describe how modern molecular methods have impacted microbiology.

Structure and Bonding Spring 2024
An introduction to the principles of chemical structure and bonding, with emphasis on their application to inorganic systems.
Topics include atoms, orbitals, and periodicity; localized bonding models; symmetry and group theory; and molecular orbital theory.
0.1 Improve general analytical and problem solving skills.
0.2 Improve physical conceptualization and 3-dimensional visualization.
1.1 Understand and use mathematical and graphical descriptions of atomic orbitals.
1.3 Understand and use orbital models and effective nuclear charge in the description of polyelectronic atoms.
1.4 Rationalize the physical origins of periodic properties and trends, and use these explanations predictively.
2.1 Construct Lewis structures from molecular formulae and predict stereochemistry using the VSEPR model.
2.2 Understand mathematical basis and properties underlying valence bond hybrid orbitals.
2.3 Construct valence bond hybrid orbitals corresponding to observed geometries.
3.1 Identify and mathematically define 3-D point symmetry operations.
4.2 Construct MO energy level diagrams for diatomic and polyatomic species using manual and symmetry-defined approaches.

The fundamental chemical and physical properties of amino acids, nucleic acids, carbohydrates and lipids are then discussed in detail.
The organization of these building blocks into more complex structures such as proteins, enzymes, polynucleotides, polysaccharides, and biological membranes will be described.
The structure and function of representative proteins such as myoglobin and hemoglobin and enzymes such as chymotrypsin will also be discussed.
Applications and importance of the above to real world situations will be provided.
Develop an understanding of the importance of aqueous solutions in biochemical processes.
Understand the basic thermodynamic principles that govern the chemistry of biological processes in both qualitative and quantitative examples
Calculate a charge of amino acids and proteins as a function of pH
Analyze the kinetic properties using the Michaelis-Menten model of enzyme kinetics
Draw the organic mechanisms for representative enzyme catalyzed reactions
Unerstand simple carbohydrate chemistry and some representative glycoprotein and glycolipid structures as well as their functions
Illustrate chemical basis of nucleotide pairing and identify different structural forms of DNA and RNA
Predict the flow of information from DNA to RNA
Compare the structure and physical properties of lipids and fatty acids, and understand their role in the formation of membrane bilayers
Take all the information learned this term and develop a deeper understanding of the chemical processes that lead to life as we know it

RCH 306
B. Power
Instructor: Bill Power
An introduction to the first, second, and third laws of thermodynamics and the application of these laws to ideal systems, mixtures, and chemical reactions.

Thermodynamic principles are used to study changes in state, including phase changes, and to establish the link between the equilibrium constant and the properties of the substances involved in a chemical reaction.
This course is a basic introduction to thermodynamics with emphasis on applications in chemistry.
The course provides the necessary background to study changes in state of many physical and chemical systems.
Define and apply the four laws of thermodynamics
Identify, describe and ultimately design a variety of physical and chemical systems through their internal changes and/or interactions with their surroundings
Quantify internal energy U, heat q, work w, enthalpy H, entropy S and Gibbs energy G in that same variety of physical and chemical systems
Predict spontaneous change in systems of varying complexity
Explain and quantify transformations involving both pure substances and mixtures using thermodynamic concepts

B. Power
Instructor: Bill Power
The use of diffusion, ultracentrifugation, osmotic pressure, electrophoresis and X-ray diffraction to study the properties of biopolymers.
This course is meant to provide you with a basic introduction to physical chemistry as applied to the life sciences with emphasis on applications in biochemistry.

This course will cover the basics of thermodynamics and their applications to biological molecules and systems, their transport properties, chemical and enzyme kinetics, and physical techniques used to establish and investigate the structures of biological macromolecules.

I will aim to provide you with all the background necessary to cover the many topics in this course, from entropy and thermodynamic principles from the 18th century to modern applications such as AI which resulted in half of the the 2024 Nobel Prize in Chemistry going to Google's DeepMind leaders Demis Hassabis and John Jumper for their development of AlphaFold, a protein structure database (of 220 million structures!).

In return you should have some familiarity with the basics of biochemistry and biological structures and terminology, as well as some comfort working with derivatives, including partial derivatives, integrals and differential equations.
Understand the four laws of thermodynamics and their applications to biological systems
Understand the importance of Gibbs free energy and chemical potential in describing physical and chemistry transformations
Understand the basics of chemical kinetics and rate laws and mechanisms
Be able to characterize enzyme kinetics using the Michaelis-Menten description and describe competition and inhibition in such mechanisms
Know how to apply and interpret structural tools such as optical and NMR spectroscopy, X-ray diffraction and computational tools to biological macromolecules

Weeks 11 to 12: NMR Spectroscopy; X-ray Diffraction; AI Methods and AlphaFold

An introduction to physics for students intending to concentrate their further studies in biology, dentistry, medicine and paramedicine; includes particle kinematics and dynamics, energy and momentum conservation, and rotational mechanics.
The main physics principles and laws covered in PHYS 111 include: “Particle kinematics and dynamics, energy and momentum conservation, and rotational mechanics.”

PHYS 111 focuses on basic physics principles and laws, on conceptual understanding and problem-solving skills, and an appreciation for the power of physics in explaining how nature works, in the contexts of both the physical and life sciences.

Physics Principles and Laws: By the end of the course, students will be able to construct scientifically sound explanations of a variety of basic physical phenomena by applying basic physics principles/laws.
define linear momentum, and calculate and compare momenta of various real-life objects;
define and calculate impulse, and establish the conditions for conservation of linear momentum; and
apply the laws of conservation of momentum and energy to collisions.
Problem-Solving Skills and Strategies: By the end of the course, students will be able to creatively apply a variety of structured problem-solving strategies:
interpret, visualize and convert the problem into a physical model (e.g., draw a free body diagram);
evaluate the result — does it make sense?
These problem-solving skills are useful in the students’ own disciplines and beyond.

An introductory course in physics for students intending to concentrate their future studies in the physical sciences, optometry, or mathematics; includes vectors (dot and cross products), particle kinematics and dynamics, forces in nature, work and energy, conservation of energy and linear momentum, rotational kinematics and dynamics, and conservation of angular momentum.
Doing Physics - quantities, dimensions, units
Point Dynamics - force, motion, Newton's laws
Conservation of Energy - work and energy, conservative systems
Conservation of linear Momentum - momentum and systems of particles
Understand the following concepts:
- Linear kinematics: the relationship between distance, velocity and acceleration.
- Linear dynamics: a consequence of forces and momentum, and how they interrelate.
- Kinetic energy, potential energy, work, and their interrelationships.
We will also re-examine these concepts in a rotating coordinate frame using angular kinematic variables along with torque and angular momentum.
6 Module 06:  Kinetic and Potential Energy
7 Module 06:  Kinetic and Potential Energy
8 Module 07:  Linear Momentum

course_name: MATH228 - Differential Equations for Physics and Chemistry (0.50)
topics: Differential Equations for Physics and Chemistry Winter 2025
First-order equations, second-order linear equations with constant coefficients, series solutions and special functions, the Laplace transform method.
Applications in physics and chemistry are emphasized.
Differential equations capture how some variable of interest, such as the position of a planet, changes as a function of some independent variable, such as time.
Differential equations are very widely used in the sciences because of the broad range of real-world phenomena they can describe in a mathematical framework.

In this course, students will be introduced to the universe of differential equations, including first-order equations, second-order linear equations, series solutions, the Laplace transform method, and both exact and numerical methods for solving differential equations.
Applications in physics and chemistry will be emphasized.
understand how differential equations can be used to model physical systems,

know how to solve various classes of differential equations using numerical methods and exact methods, and

Unit 8 - Systems of Differential Equations (Weeks 11 - 12)

topics: Notice of Recording
Computational Modelling of Cellular Systems Winter 2024
B. Ingalls
An introduction to dynamic mathematical modeling of cellular processes.
The emphasis is on using computational tools to investigate differential equation-based models.
This course provides an introduction to dynamic mathematical modeling of cellular processes.
The emphasis will be on using computational tools to investigate models of cellular phenomena.
The course then addresses models in four biological domains: metabolic networks, signal transduction pathways, gene regulatory networks and electrophysiology.

course_name: BIOL439 - Environmental and Natural Products Biochemistry (0.50)
topics: Environmental and Natural Products Biochemistry Fall 2024
okey.igboeli@uwaterloo.ca
This course deals with the functions, distribution, and environmental ramifications of natural compounds produced by plants and other biological systems.

Natural products are those compounds usually described as secondary metabolites, i.e., those apparently non-essential products whose physiological and ecological functions are either obscure or are of peripheral importance to the organism.

However, many of these non-essential products have profound competitive, economic, and pharmacological significance; and as research proceeds, their physiological roles within the parent organisms are becoming clearer.
As well, this course has a strong emphasis on how environmental chemical and physical processes impact on living organisms and their biochemistry.
Describe the importance of physical, biological, and environmental concepts related to plant secondary metabolites.
Integrate physical, biological, and environmental concepts related to different plant secondary metabolites.
Introduction: Products of primary and secondary metabolism.
Importance of secondary metabolites.
Plant-derived pharmaceutical compounds
Some of the papers are background on different subjects covered, others are examples of current research involving environmental and natural products biochemistry.

This course includes the independent development and practice of specific skills, such as discussion of new knowledge in the field of natural products and their competitive, economic, and pharmacological significance.

A survey of the recent advances in the vertebrate immune response; the cells and tissues of the lymphoid system; humoral and cell-mediated immunity; initiation and regulation of the immune response; the immune system and disease, emerging techniques used in immunology.

Identify the appropriate technique and corresponding controls to generate high-quality, meaningful data.

Each week students will be reading scientific literature on the topics to be discussed in class – links to these articles will be posted on Learn and students are responsible for accessing and reading these papers.

While ~50% of Midterm #2 will mainly focus on material covered after Midterm #1, Midterm #2 is cumulative and students should still have an excellent mastery of the material covered in the first half of the course as the immune system is interconnected and many of the same techniques are used in immunology research.
Thus, students are still expected to know these immunology concepts and techniques.

However, students should should have a mastery of the material such that they could complete the midterm without course materials as there is not enough time to learn material during exams – lecture notes and papers are for quick reference in case you have forgotten a detail.
Group Oral Presentations: Presentations will be a critique of the paper and will be approximately 25 minutes in length followed by ~5 minutes for questions.
