Chemistry 360 builds on the concepts and chemistry taught in CHEM 264 and CHEM 265.
If you want to do well in CHEM 360, you should re-familiarize yourself with some of the material in your introductory organic chemistry courses.
More specifically, CHEM 360 will familiarize students with some of the modern synthetic methods for the formation of carbon-carbon sigma bonds in organic compounds.

An array of anionic, cationic, pericyclic, and organometallic methods will be introduced as part of three general sections, and the factors governing the mechanistic, stereochemical and regiochemical course of these processes will be presented and discussed as appropriate.

Section 1 will cover enols and enolates, condensations and a-substitutions of carbonyl compounds (acid- and base-catalyzed), and conjugate addition to a,b-unsaturated carbonyl compounds (acid- and base-catalyzed).

Section 2  will cover pericyclic reactions (cycloadditions under thermal and photochemical conditions), with an emphasis on how an appreciation of frontier molecular orbitals allows for prediction of the reactivity of the systems (thermal and photochemical conditions), as well as relative reaction rates, regiochemistry and stereochemistry.
Section 3  will present transition-metal catalysis and organometallic reactions, with a particular emphasis on Pd-catalyzed cross-coupling reactions.
1) To learn to use curve arrow formalism to “push” pairs of electrons in writing resonance forms and in sketching electron flow in chemical reactions.
To be able to use the understanding of reactions mechanisms to predict the outcome of these chemical reactions (mechanistic reasoning to interpret pattern of reactivity).

4) To be able to identify intermediates versus transition states in an energy diagram for all fundamental condensation reactions and be able to determine the difference between kinetically and thermodynamically controlled reactions, identify equilibrium and reaction rates, and relate to the energy of the transitions state, starting material, and final products.
7) To be able to identify neutral cyclic transitions states, involving bond-forming and bond-breaking events, in cycloaddition reactions, under thermal and photochemical conditions.

To be able to use frontier molecular orbitals (FMO’s) to predict the reactivity of cycloadditions under thermal and photochemical conditions, as well as relative reaction rates, regiochemistry and stereochemistry (Endo rule).

11) To be able to generate catalytic cycles for common cross-coupling reactions, namely Suzuki, Stille, Heck, Sonogashira, and Buchwald-Hartwig (Buchwald-Hartwig amination), as well as variations involving carbon monoxide.

Food preservation, spoilage, poisoning and modern concepts in quality assurance programs are studied.
Microorganisms interact with the human food supply in a number of ways; some we consider beneficial, others detrimental.
In this course we'll look at factors that influence microbial growth in food.
If uncontrolled, such growth can lead to food spoilage, and, in some cases the safety of the food may be compromised.
Techniques to preserve foods, thereby extending their shelf-life and reducing potential health hazards, will be considered.

Determine appropriate techniques for microbial analysis of food and for food preservation

Exams
Pseudo-cumulative means the exams aren't cumulative in the sense that each successive exam covers all content since the beginning of the course.

However, while each exam is primarily focussed on material since the previous exam, there may be a small number of questions related to core concepts and major important ideas from throughout the course.

My perspective on the cumulative aspects of the course is that there are certain 'big ideas' or 'core concepts' that I need to know and be aware of to be a successful and productive researcher, and then there are lots of specific details that I know are in a book on my shelf or just a quick internet search away.

The role of classical genetic analysis in the context of today's genomic era.
Methods used in model eukaryotic genetic organisms such as forward and reverse genetic screens, genetic mosaics, conditional mutants, and genetic mapping will be discussed.

Examples will illustrate how genes continue to be identified using classical-based approaches in a variety of biological processes, including cell cycle progression, cancer and metastasis, learning and memory, as well as pattern formation and embryonic development.
Alternatives to traditional mutagenesis-based screens and the links between classical and molecular genetics will also be discussed.

This course also strives to introduce students to some advanced concepts in classical genetics and to relate how classical genetics is relevant in today’s era of genome sequencing, genomics, proteomics, and genome editing.
1) Introduction & Review of 239 Material:

Prokaryotes vs. eukaryotes, Mendel’s Rules (two main laws), the dihybrib cross, the concept of genetic linkage, the stages of meiosis and the main events of meiosis, the chromosome theory of inheritance and its proof, recombination mapping (genetic distances), genetic maps vs. physical maps, polytene chromosomes.
2) Concepts for Genetic Analysis:

Model genetic organisms (general attributes and characteristics), balancer chromosomes and “balanced” genetic stocks, pericentric and paracentric inversions, methods of inducing genetic mutations, heterochromatin, RNAi, the genetic engineering and use of transposons as genetic tools
3) Details of Drosophila as a model genetic organism (MGO)
Tetrad Analysis in Saccharomyces cerevisiae, Perkin’s Equation, Centromere Linkage in Ordered and Unordered Tetrads, Half Tetrad Analysis, crossover interference, sister chromatid exchange.
8) non-Mendelian Inheritance
Knowing how the complementation test can fool you, genetic modifiers, examples of genetic screens using MGOs, epistasis
11) CRISPR/Cas9 –– implications for model genetic systems and efficacy for gene therapy, and “genome editing”
Regain familiarity with the concepts introduced in BIOL 239, such as Mendel’s laws and classical based genetic analysis
Be in a good position to consider and evaluate possible graduate school projects in the areas of basic biomedical research, developmental or molecular biology
Learn to appreciate the laws of inheritance and exactly why organisms such as flies, worms, and yeasts have become major tools of basic research in genetics, cell biology, and developmental biology

course_name: CHEM310 - Transition Element Compounds and Inorganic Materials (0.50)
topics: The inorganic, organic, and solid state chemistry of the d-block elements.
The structure and physical properties of co-ordination compounds and transition metal containing solids.
The role of transition metal organometallics in catalysis.

The first (and major) part of the course will cover the chemistry and electronic structure of simple coordination compounds; the effects of ligand fields on magnetism, electronic spectra, substitution and redox behaviour will be examined.
In the second part, the properties of transition metal containing solids will be discussed along with the uses of these systems in, for example, lasers, and heterogeneous catalysts.
• Understand the important roles that transition metal inorganic chemistry plays in materials and biological processes;
• Describe and explain the bonding inherent to transition metal inorganic complexes;
• Discuss the impact and influence of the unpaired electrons in the d-block elements in the spectroscopic, optical and magnetic properties of the materials and proteins that contain them;
• Apply basic crystal field and molecular orbital concepts to explain the structures of coordination complexes.
Configuration of d-elements, d-orbitals and shapes of coordination complexes.
Crystal field effects in transition metal chemistry.
Module 2: Symmetry, group theory, and character tables for inorganic complexes.
Metal-ligand σ and π-bonding, and the origin of the spectro-electrochemical series.
Module 4: Optical and Magnetic properties of TM complexes.
Electronic and charge-transfer spectra of transition metal ions.
Magnetic behaviour of metal ions.
Descriptive chemistry of various geometries and the complexes that form them.
Reduction and oxidation chemistry of the transition metal elements
Substitutions; thermodynamic and kinetic stability; mechanisms of redox reactions in proteins.
Carbonyl complexes and metallocenes.

In the Winter 2025 term the focus of the course will be electronic structure theory and a smaller segment on coupled electron-nuclear motion, developing theory beyond the Born Oppenheimer approximation.
The course will cover a description of the basic electronic structure problem introducing an atomic orbital basis set, Slater determinants and the Slater-Condon rules.
In another segment we will discuss vibronic coupling, introducing diabatic electronic states and simple model problems and introduce techniques to solve them using simple Python programs.

Have introductory understanding of non-adiabatic nuclear dynamics going beyond the Born-Oppenheimer approximation.

Situation

What does it mean to be a cell biologist?
One group of scientists might explore growing tissues in a laboratory to one day produce artificial skin or organs.

No matter what their question, cell biologists use a similar set of laboratory skills that allow them to peek inside the tiniest of biological units that make up the diversity of organisms we see around us.

Although fundamental techniques like microscopy have hugely advanced since the invention of the light microscope, every cell biologist needs to learn how to properly use a microscope to see cells reliably.
These can be very tricky to use properly but doing so could be the difference between a world-changing discovery and an experiment that no one can replicate.
These and other methods that are integral to working in the cell biology field will be introduced in this laboratory and it is my hope that you will leave confident in these fundamental techniques.
Maintain a well-organized and comprehensive lab book.
Identify elements of a well-structured laboratory report and write some elements of a lab report.

okey.igboeli@uwaterloo.ca
This course deals with the functions, distribution, and environmental ramifications of natural compounds produced by plants and other biological systems.

Natural products are those compounds usually described as secondary metabolites, i.e., those apparently non-essential products whose physiological and ecological functions are either obscure or are of peripheral importance to the organism.

However, many of these non-essential products have profound competitive, economic, and pharmacological significance; and as research proceeds, their physiological roles within the parent organisms are becoming clearer.
As well, this course has a strong emphasis on how environmental chemical and physical processes impact on living organisms and their biochemistry.
Describe the importance of physical, biological, and environmental concepts related to plant secondary metabolites.
Integrate physical, biological, and environmental concepts related to different plant secondary metabolites.
Introduction: Products of primary and secondary metabolism.
Importance of secondary metabolites.
Plant-derived pharmaceutical compounds
Some of the papers are background on different subjects covered, others are examples of current research involving environmental and natural products biochemistry.

This course includes the independent development and practice of specific skills, such as discussion of new knowledge in the field of natural products and their competitive, economic, and pharmacological significance.

topics: Structure and Bonding Spring 2024
An introduction to the principles of chemical structure and bonding, with emphasis on their application to inorganic systems.
Topics include atoms, orbitals, and periodicity; localized bonding models; symmetry and group theory; and molecular orbital theory.
0.1 Improve general analytical and problem solving skills.
0.2 Improve physical conceptualization and 3-dimensional visualization.
1.1 Understand and use mathematical and graphical descriptions of atomic orbitals.
1.3 Understand and use orbital models and effective nuclear charge in the description of polyelectronic atoms.
1.4 Rationalize the physical origins of periodic properties and trends, and use these explanations predictively.
2.1 Construct Lewis structures from molecular formulae and predict stereochemistry using the VSEPR model.
2.2 Understand mathematical basis and properties underlying valence bond hybrid orbitals.
2.3 Construct valence bond hybrid orbitals corresponding to observed geometries.
3.1 Identify and mathematically define 3-D point symmetry operations.
4.2 Construct MO energy level diagrams for diatomic and polyatomic species using manual and symmetry-defined approaches.

The fundamental chemical and physical properties of amino acids, nucleic acids, carbohydrates and lipids are then discussed in detail.
The organization of these building blocks into more complex structures such as proteins, enzymes, polynucleotides, polysaccharides, and biological membranes will be described.
The structure and function of representative proteins such as myoglobin and hemoglobin and enzymes such as chymotrypsin will also be discussed.
Applications and importance of the above to real world situations will be provided.
Develop an understanding of the importance of aqueous solutions in biochemical processes.
Understand the basic thermodynamic principles that govern the chemistry of biological processes in both qualitative and quantitative examples
Calculate a charge of amino acids and proteins as a function of pH
Analyze the kinetic properties using the Michaelis-Menten model of enzyme kinetics
Draw the organic mechanisms for representative enzyme catalyzed reactions
Unerstand simple carbohydrate chemistry and some representative glycoprotein and glycolipid structures as well as their functions
Illustrate chemical basis of nucleotide pairing and identify different structural forms of DNA and RNA
Predict the flow of information from DNA to RNA
Compare the structure and physical properties of lipids and fatty acids, and understand their role in the formation of membrane bilayers
Take all the information learned this term and develop a deeper understanding of the chemical processes that lead to life as we know it

major_name: Biochemistry - Biotechnology Specialization (Bachelor of Science - Honours)
topics: RCH 306
B. Power
Instructor: Bill Power
An introduction to the first, second, and third laws of thermodynamics and the application of these laws to ideal systems, mixtures, and chemical reactions.

Thermodynamic principles are used to study changes in state, including phase changes, and to establish the link between the equilibrium constant and the properties of the substances involved in a chemical reaction.
This course is a basic introduction to thermodynamics with emphasis on applications in chemistry.
The course provides the necessary background to study changes in state of many physical and chemical systems.
Define and apply the four laws of thermodynamics
Identify, describe and ultimately design a variety of physical and chemical systems through their internal changes and/or interactions with their surroundings
Quantify internal energy U, heat q, work w, enthalpy H, entropy S and Gibbs energy G in that same variety of physical and chemical systems
Predict spontaneous change in systems of varying complexity
Explain and quantify transformations involving both pure substances and mixtures using thermodynamic concepts

major_name: Biochemistry - Biotechnology Specialization (Bachelor of Science - Honours)
topics: Physical Biochemistry Winter 2025
B. Power
Instructor: Bill Power
The use of diffusion, ultracentrifugation, osmotic pressure, electrophoresis and X-ray diffraction to study the properties of biopolymers.
This course is meant to provide you with a basic introduction to physical chemistry as applied to the life sciences with emphasis on applications in biochemistry.

This course will cover the basics of thermodynamics and their applications to biological molecules and systems, their transport properties, chemical and enzyme kinetics, and physical techniques used to establish and investigate the structures of biological macromolecules.

I will aim to provide you with all the background necessary to cover the many topics in this course, from entropy and thermodynamic principles from the 18th century to modern applications such as AI which resulted in half of the the 2024 Nobel Prize in Chemistry going to Google's DeepMind leaders Demis Hassabis and John Jumper for their development of AlphaFold, a protein structure database (of 220 million structures!).

In return you should have some familiarity with the basics of biochemistry and biological structures and terminology, as well as some comfort working with derivatives, including partial derivatives, integrals and differential equations.
Understand the four laws of thermodynamics and their applications to biological systems
Understand the importance of Gibbs free energy and chemical potential in describing physical and chemistry transformations
Understand the basics of chemical kinetics and rate laws and mechanisms
Be able to characterize enzyme kinetics using the Michaelis-Menten description and describe competition and inhibition in such mechanisms
Know how to apply and interpret structural tools such as optical and NMR spectroscopy, X-ray diffraction and computational tools to biological macromolecules
There will be online and in-class assignments, on a rotating interval of about two weeks.
It will occur in a 2.5 hour time slot sometime between April 9 and April 25 (I have no control over this scheduling).
Weeks 1 to 3:   Thermodynamics, its Laws and its Applications
Week 10:            Biomolecular Structure; Optical Spectroscopy
Weeks 11 to 12: NMR Spectroscopy; X-ray Diffraction; AI Methods and AlphaFold

course_name: MATH228 - Differential Equations for Physics and Chemistry (0.50)
major_name: Biochemistry - Biotechnology Specialization (Bachelor of Science - Honours)
topics: Differential Equations for Physics and Chemistry Winter 2025
First-order equations, second-order linear equations with constant coefficients, series solutions and special functions, the Laplace transform method.
Applications in physics and chemistry are emphasized.
Differential equations capture how some variable of interest, such as the position of a planet, changes as a function of some independent variable, such as time.
Differential equations are very widely used in the sciences because of the broad range of real-world phenomena they can describe in a mathematical framework.

In this course, students will be introduced to the universe of differential equations, including first-order equations, second-order linear equations, series solutions, the Laplace transform method, and both exact and numerical methods for solving differential equations.
Applications in physics and chemistry will be emphasized.
understand how differential equations can be used to model physical systems,
know how to classify differential equations,
know how to solve various classes of differential equations using numerical methods and exact methods, and
Unit 2 - First-Order Differential Equations (Weeks 2 - 3)
Unit 3 - Second-Order Linear Equations (Weeks 4 - 5)
Unit 4 - Mechanical and Electrical Vibrations (Week 6)
Unit 5 - Series Solutions of Second-Order Linear Equations (Weeks 7 - 8)
Unit 8 - Systems of Differential Equations (Weeks 11 - 12)

topics: An introduction to physics for students intending to concentrate their further studies in biology, dentistry, medicine and paramedicine; includes particle kinematics and dynamics, energy and momentum conservation, and rotational mechanics.
The main physics principles and laws covered in PHYS 111 include: “Particle kinematics and dynamics, energy and momentum conservation, and rotational mechanics.”

PHYS 111 focuses on basic physics principles and laws, on conceptual understanding and problem-solving skills, and an appreciation for the power of physics in explaining how nature works, in the contexts of both the physical and life sciences.

Physics Principles and Laws: By the end of the course, students will be able to construct scientifically sound explanations of a variety of basic physical phenomena by applying basic physics principles/laws.
define linear momentum, and calculate and compare momenta of various real-life objects;
define and calculate impulse, and establish the conditions for conservation of linear momentum; and
apply the laws of conservation of momentum and energy to collisions.
Problem-Solving Skills and Strategies: By the end of the course, students will be able to creatively apply a variety of structured problem-solving strategies:
interpret, visualize and convert the problem into a physical model (e.g., draw a free body diagram);
evaluate the result — does it make sense?
These problem-solving skills are useful in the students’ own disciplines and beyond.

topics: An introductory course in physics for students intending to concentrate their future studies in the physical sciences, optometry, or mathematics; includes vectors (dot and cross products), particle kinematics and dynamics, forces in nature, work and energy, conservation of energy and linear momentum, rotational kinematics and dynamics, and conservation of angular momentum.
Doing Physics - quantities, dimensions, units
Point Dynamics - force, motion, Newton's laws
Conservation of Energy - work and energy, conservative systems
Conservation of linear Momentum - momentum and systems of particles
Understand the following concepts:
- Linear kinematics: the relationship between distance, velocity and acceleration.
- Linear dynamics: a consequence of forces and momentum, and how they interrelate.
- Kinetic energy, potential energy, work, and their interrelationships.
We will also re-examine these concepts in a rotating coordinate frame using angular kinematic variables along with torque and angular momentum.

course_name: AMATH382 - Computational Modelling of Cellular Systems (0.50)
major_name: Biochemistry - Biotechnology Specialization (Bachelor of Science - Honours)
topics: Notice of Recording
Computational Modelling of Cellular Systems Winter 2024
B. Ingalls
An introduction to dynamic mathematical modeling of cellular processes.
The emphasis is on using computational tools to investigate differential equation-based models.
This course provides an introduction to dynamic mathematical modeling of cellular processes.
The emphasis will be on using computational tools to investigate models of cellular phenomena.
The course then addresses models in four biological domains: metabolic networks, signal transduction pathways, gene regulatory networks and electrophysiology.
Intended Audience: Third and fourth year students interested in dynamic modelling in molecular cell biology.
Software: We will be making heavy use of packages for numerical simulation of differential equations.
Appendix C of the course notes consists of tutorials on MATLAB and XPPAUT, which is a GUI-based package for dynamical systems analysis.
Design and simulate ordinary differential equation models of chemical reaction networks
Investigate differential equation models using phase plane analysis, sensitivity analysis, and bifurcation analysis
Develop and interpret differential equation models of biomolecular networks in the context of cellular metabolism, signal transduction, gene regulation, and electrophysiology
Design and simulate stochastic models of gene regulatory networks
Provide critical analysis of kinetic models of intracellular networks in the scientific literature and communicate their potential and limitations
Kinetic Modelling of Biochemical Networks
Module 3. Dynamics and Stability

This course will provide students with an understanding of the fundamental concepts of the vertebrate immune system.
Topics will focus on the components of the immune system, innate and adaptive immunity, immune cell development, communication, and recognition of non-self leading to an immune response.
How organisms regulate health versus disease is a central concept in the life sciences and has been the subject of intense study for over 100 years.
Describe the physical, chemical, cellular and soluble mediators of the immune system and how they are generated
Explain how pathogens are recognized by the immune system and how this recognition initiates innate and adaptive immunity
Determine how the innate immune system activates and drives the type of immune response towards a pathogen
Indicate how resolution of infection occurs and the cells and molecules involved
Predict how a defect in an aspect of immunity or evasion of the immune system by a pathogen will impact components of the immune response and affect the resolution of an infection

major_name: Biochemistry - Biotechnology Specialization (Bachelor of Science - Honours)
topics: Email: graham.murphy@uwaterloo.ca
FMO theory, organometallics, and transition metal-catalyzed C-C bond formation.
Chemistry 360 builds on the concepts and chemistry taught in CHEM 264 and CHEM 265.
If you want to do well in CHEM 360, you should re-familiarize yourself with some of the material in your introductory organic chemistry courses.
More specifically, CHEM 360 will familiarize students with some of the modern synthetic methods for the formation of carbon-carbon sigma bonds in organic compounds.

An array of anionic, cationic, pericyclic, and organometallic methods will be introduced as part of three general sections, and the factors governing the mechanistic, stereochemical and regiochemical course of these processes will be presented and discussed as appropriate.

Section 1 will cover enols and enolates, condensations and a-substitutions of carbonyl compounds (acid- and base-catalyzed), and conjugate addition to a,b-unsaturated carbonyl compounds (acid- and base-catalyzed).

Section 2  will cover pericyclic reactions (cycloadditions under thermal and photochemical conditions), with an emphasis on how an appreciation of frontier molecular orbitals allows for prediction of the reactivity of the systems (thermal and photochemical conditions), as well as relative reaction rates, regiochemistry and stereochemistry.
Section 3  will present transition-metal catalysis and organometallic reactions, with a particular emphasis on Pd-catalyzed cross-coupling reactions.
1) To learn to use curve arrow formalism to “push” pairs of electrons in writing resonance forms and in sketching electron flow in chemical reactions.
To be able to use the understanding of reactions mechanisms to predict the outcome of these chemical reactions (mechanistic reasoning to interpret pattern of reactivity).

4) To be able to identify intermediates versus transition states in an energy diagram for all fundamental condensation reactions and be able to determine the difference between kinetically and thermodynamically controlled reactions, identify equilibrium and reaction rates, and relate to the energy of the transitions state, starting material, and final products.
7) To be able to identify neutral cyclic transitions states, involving bond-forming and bond-breaking events, in cycloaddition reactions, under thermal and photochemical conditions.

To be able to use frontier molecular orbitals (FMO’s) to predict the reactivity of cycloadditions under thermal and photochemical conditions, as well as relative reaction rates, regiochemistry and stereochemistry (Endo rule).

11) To be able to generate catalytic cycles for common cross-coupling reactions, namely Suzuki, Stille, Heck, Sonogashira, and Buchwald-Hartwig (Buchwald-Hartwig amination), as well as variations involving carbon monoxide.

cheryl.duxbury@uwaterloo.ca
cheryl.duxbury@uwaterloo.ca
cheryl.duxbury@uwaterloo.ca

ca
Food preservation, spoilage, poisoning and modern concepts in quality assurance programs are studied.
Microorganisms interact with the human food supply in a number of ways; some we consider beneficial, others detrimental.
In this course we'll look at factors that influence microbial growth in food.
If uncontrolled, such growth can lead to food spoilage, and, in some cases the safety of the food may be compromised.
Techniques to preserve foods, thereby extending their shelf-life and reducing potential health hazards, will be considered.

Differentiate between microbes as spoilage organisms, pathogens, and useful food fermenters

Determine appropriate techniques for microbial analysis of food and for food preservation

topics: Heidi Engelhardt
The physiology of major organ systems of the human body.
Topics include the central nervous system, the sense organs, the digestive system, the endocrine system, the reproductive system, and the excretory system.
View requirements for BIOL 373
This course explores the physiology of several major organ systems of the human body.
Topics include the central nervous system, sensory physiology, endocrine regulatory mechanisms, renal function, digestion, the endocrine control of metabolism and growth, and reproduction.
The combination of BIOL 273 and BIOL 373 covers all the major physiological systems.
The course is designed for students with a basic understanding of the structures of the biologically relevant macromolecules and cell biology (as provided by the BIOL 130 prerequisite).

major_name: Biochemistry - Biotechnology Specialization (Bachelor of Science - Honours)
topics: Advanced Eukaryotic Genetics Winter 2025
I will generally send a brief response within 24h – but do not expect lengthy email responses.
The role of classical genetic analysis in the context of today's genomic era.
Methods used in model eukaryotic genetic organisms such as forward and reverse genetic screens, genetic mosaics, conditional mutants, and genetic mapping will be discussed.

Examples will illustrate how genes continue to be identified using classical-based approaches in a variety of biological processes, including cell cycle progression, cancer and metastasis, learning and memory, as well as pattern formation and embryonic development.
Alternatives to traditional mutagenesis-based screens and the links between classical and molecular genetics will also be discussed.

This course also strives to introduce students to some advanced concepts in classical genetics and to relate how classical genetics is relevant in today’s era of genome sequencing, genomics, proteomics, and genome editing.
1) Introduction & Review of 239 Material:

Prokaryotes vs. eukaryotes, Mendel’s Rules (two main laws), the dihybrib cross, the concept of genetic linkage, the stages of meiosis and the main events of meiosis, the chromosome theory of inheritance and its proof, recombination mapping (genetic distances), genetic maps vs. physical maps, polytene chromosomes.
2) Concepts for Genetic Analysis:

Model genetic organisms (general attributes and characteristics), balancer chromosomes and “balanced” genetic stocks, pericentric and paracentric inversions, methods of inducing genetic mutations, heterochromatin, RNAi, the genetic engineering and use of transposons as genetic tools
3) Details of Drosophila as a model genetic organism (MGO)
Tetrad Analysis in Saccharomyces cerevisiae, Perkin’s Equation, Centromere Linkage in Ordered and Unordered Tetrads, Half Tetrad Analysis, crossover interference, sister chromatid exchange.
8) non-Mendelian Inheritance
Knowing how the complementation test can fool you, genetic modifiers, examples of genetic screens using MGOs, epistasis
11) CRISPR/Cas9 –– implications for model genetic systems and efficacy for gene therapy, and “genome editing”
Regain familiarity with the concepts introduced in BIOL 239, such as Mendel’s laws and classical based genetic analysis
Be in a good position to consider and evaluate possible graduate school projects in the areas of basic biomedical research, developmental or molecular biology
Learn to appreciate the laws of inheritance and exactly why organisms such as flies, worms, and yeasts have become major tools of basic research in genetics, cell biology, and developmental biology

major_name: Biochemistry - Biotechnology Specialization (Bachelor of Science - Honours)
topics: The inorganic, organic, and solid state chemistry of the d-block elements.
The structure and physical properties of co-ordination compounds and transition metal containing solids.
The role of transition metal organometallics in catalysis.

The first (and major) part of the course will cover the chemistry and electronic structure of simple coordination compounds; the effects of ligand fields on magnetism, electronic spectra, substitution and redox behaviour will be examined.
In the second part, the properties of transition metal containing solids will be discussed along with the uses of these systems in, for example, lasers, and heterogeneous catalysts.
• Understand the important roles that transition metal inorganic chemistry plays in materials and biological processes;
• Describe and explain the bonding inherent to transition metal inorganic complexes;
• Discuss the impact and influence of the unpaired electrons in the d-block elements in the spectroscopic, optical and magnetic properties of the materials and proteins that contain them;
• Apply basic crystal field and molecular orbital concepts to explain the structures of coordination complexes.
Configuration of d-elements, d-orbitals and shapes of coordination complexes.
Crystal field effects in transition metal chemistry.
Module 2: Symmetry, group theory, and character tables for inorganic complexes.
Metal-ligand σ and π-bonding, and the origin of the spectro-electrochemical series.
Module 4: Optical and Magnetic properties of TM complexes.
Electronic and charge-transfer spectra of transition metal ions.
Magnetic behaviour of metal ions.
Descriptive chemistry of various geometries and the complexes that form them.
Reduction and oxidation chemistry of the transition metal elements
Substitutions; thermodynamic and kinetic stability; mechanisms of redox reactions in proteins.
Carbonyl complexes and metallocenes.

topics: Notice of Recording

A selection of current and advanced topics of interests in many areas of chemistry.
"Quantum Mechanics in Chemistry" is the title for this section of Chem400

In the Winter 2025 term the focus of the course will be electronic structure theory and a smaller segment on coupled electron-nuclear motion, developing theory beyond the Born Oppenheimer approximation.
The course will cover a description of the basic electronic structure problem introducing an atomic orbital basis set, Slater determinants and the Slater-Condon rules.
In another segment we will discuss vibronic coupling, introducing diabatic electronic states and simple model problems and introduce techniques to solve them using simple Python programs.
Have a good understanding of the electronic structure problem in Chemistry and how it connects to thermochemistry.
Have an in depth understanding of the Hartree-Fock method and the basic Hartree-Fock algorithm.
Be able to construct Hamiltonian matrix for small problems using Slater-Condon rules
Have introductory knowledge of Coupled Cluster methods for ground and excited states, and the concept of size-consistency.
Have introductory understanding of non-adiabatic nuclear dynamics going beyond the Born-Oppenheimer approximation.
Week 1,2: General introduction to quantum mechanics and the main uses in chemistry / thermochemistry.
Discussion of fundamental principles of Density Functional Theory.
Extension to multiple electronic surfaces.
Vibronic models beyond Born-Oppenheimer.

topics: STC 4018

However, we do run multiple labs at the same time which means we may not always be in the office.
Situation
Please email Dr. Gurska directly at jola.gurska@uwaterloo.ca
What does it mean to be a cell biologist?
One group of scientists might explore growing tissues in a laboratory to one day produce artificial skin or organs.

No matter what their question, cell biologists use a similar set of laboratory skills that allow them to peek inside the tiniest of biological units that make up the diversity of organisms we see around us.

Although fundamental techniques like microscopy have hugely advanced since the invention of the light microscope, every cell biologist needs to learn how to properly use a microscope to see cells reliably.
These can be very tricky to use properly but doing so could be the difference between a world-changing discovery and an experiment that no one can replicate.
These and other methods that are integral to working in the cell biology field will be introduced in this laboratory and it is my hope that you will leave confident in these fundamental techniques.
Maintain a well-organized and comprehensive lab book.
Identify elements of a well-structured laboratory report and write some elements of a lab report.

major_name: Biological and Medical Physics (Bachelor of Science - Honours)
topics: General Chemistry 1 Winter 2025
RCH 101
The stoichiometry of compounds and chemical reactions.
Energy changes in chemical systems.
Electronic structure of atoms and molecules; correlation with the chemical reactivity of common elements, inorganic and organic compounds.
The second part of this course is concerned with explaining periodicity and trends in chemical reactivity in terms of the electronic structure of atoms and molecules.

Topics covered in this part of the course include the quantum theory of the hydrogen atom; electron configurations in multi-electron atoms; ionic and covalent bonding; Lewis structures, valence shell electron repulsion theory and molecular geometry; quantum mechanical bonding theories, including valence bond theory and molecular orbital theory.
Additional topics may include an introduction to electron-transfer reactions, including the assignment of oxidation states and the balancing of oxidation-reduction reactions.
assess the greenness of a chemical reaction using Atom Economy and E-Factor metrics.
describe the electronic structure of atoms in terms of quantum theory using atomic orbitals and quantum numbers.
justify the organization of the periodic table and predict trends in the properties of the elements.
describe bonding in molecules in terms of atomic orbitals and molecular orbitals, and explain molecular shape and stability in terms of electron count.
describe the interactions of molecules in solids, liquids, and gases to compare physical and reactive properties.
